title: Southwest College of Naturopathic Medicine
description: The Southwest College of Naturopathic Medicine is a naturopathic college located in Tempe, Arizona that teaches naturopathic medicine and acupuncture/oriental medicine. As of 2022, faculty is dominated by people without medical degrees.[1] None of the three deans have MD degrees. Three of 18 faculty in the School of Naturopathic Medicine, one of 16 faculty in the School of Nutrition has an MD, and four of the 53 adjunct faculty have MD degrees.[1] As of 2022, the college is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission and the Council on Naturopathic Medical Education.[2] Quackwatch strongly advises against attending a naturopathic school.[3] As of September 26, 2022, the college will be changing its name to the Sonoran University of Health Sciences.[4]
cleaned_text: Southwest College of Naturopathic Medicine [Jump to navigation](#mw-head) [Jump to search](#searchInput) |Against allopathy| The Southwest College of Naturopathic Medicine is a [naturopathic](/wiki/Naturopathy) college located in Tempe, [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona) that teaches naturopathic medicine and [acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture)/oriental medicine. As of 2022, faculty is dominated by people without medical degrees. [[1]](#cite_note-faculty-1) None of the three deans have MD degrees. Three of 18 faculty in the School of Naturopathic Medicine, one of 16 faculty in the School of Nutrition has an MD, and four of the 53 adjunct faculty have MD degrees. [[1]](#cite_note-faculty-1) As of 2022, the college is accredited by the Higher Learning Commission and the Council on Naturopathic Medical Education. [[2]](#cite_note-2) Quackwatch strongly advises against attending a naturopathic school. [[3]](#cite_note-3) As of September 26, 2022, the college will be changing its name to the Sonoran University of Health Sciences. [[4]](#cite_note-4) Despite annual [influenza](/wiki/Influenza) vaccinations being effective for prevention, SCNM has instead recommended ineffective vitamins and minerals, botanical medicine and lifestyle recommendation for preventing the flu. [[5]](#cite_note-5) Although SCNM both requires and administers vaccinations ( [Hepatitis B](/wiki/Hepatitis_B), [MMR](/wiki/MMR_vaccine), [COVID](/wiki/COVID)), their allowed exemptions are broad, allowing by medical and religious exemptions. [[6]](#cite_note-6) | |[Quackwatch](/wiki/Quackwatch)says: [[7]](#cite_note-7) Academics[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Southwest_College_of_Naturopathic_Medicine&action=edit§ion=1)] programs: [[8]](#cite_note-8) [Doctorate of Naturopathic Medicine (ND)](/wiki/Alternative_Medicine_Education) - Concurrent Masters of Public Health (MPH) in conjunction with the University of Arizona (UA) — Notably, the MPH is administered and taught entirely through UA, and credits are transferrable from UA to SCNM but not vice versa. [[9]](#cite_note-9) - Concurrent acupuncture license (LAc) administered and taught through the Phoenix Institute of Herbal Medicine and Acupuncture [[10]](#cite_note-10) - Master of Science in Clinical Nutrition (MSCN) - Executive Master of Science in Nutrition Business Leadership (MSNBL) Research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Southwest_College_of_Naturopathic_Medicine&action=edit§ion=2)] The former Chief Medical Officer at SCNM, Thomas A. Kruzel (ND), made the preposterous claim that "The early detection of multiple sclerosis by " [pulse](/wiki/Pulse_diagnosis)" and "tongue" diagnosis, such as to effect a cure by [hydrotherapy](/wiki/Hydrotherapy), [homeopathy](/wiki/Homeopathy), [acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture), diet, and other methods." [[11]](#cite_note-11) [[12]](#cite_note-12) Given the large faculty of the college that includes people with actual MDs and PhDs, there is a paucity of [peer-reviewed](/wiki/Peer-reviewed) published research by the faculty in non- [crank](/wiki/Crank) journals. According to their website, the complete list of publications through 2021. A few submitted-but-unpublished papers are not included here — actual scientists don't get participation prizes. [[13]](#cite_note-13) |Read it and weep| | | Residencies[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Southwest_College_of_Naturopathic_Medicine&action=edit§ion=3)] The only type of residencies are in primary care practice, which is controversial considering that the medical community regards naturopathic medicine as [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience). [[14]](#cite_note-14) Arizona has the "broadest naturopathic scope of practice" and "may be the worst-case scenario of any state licensing pseudoscience as medicine." [[15]](#cite_note-wildwest-15) Unlike many states, Arizona allows NDs to administer substances (including vitamins, pharmaceuticals, and natural substances) intravenously, and conduct minor surgery (though what 'minor' is is not defined in the law) [[15]](#cite_note-wildwest-15) [[16]](#cite_note-16) IV administration is such a favorite procedure at SCNM, that it alluded to in their website's page-not-found (404) error message with "Uh Oh, 404 — Vein Not Found". [[17]](#cite_note-17) Clinics[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Southwest_College_of_Naturopathic_Medicine&action=edit§ion=4)] SCNM offers medical clinics on and off campus, they include regular naturopathic care, [HIV/AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS) care, [addiction](/wiki/Addiction) support, and one for [abused women](/wiki/Domestic_violence) and [children](/wiki/Child_abuse). [[18]](#cite_note-18) - Hamilton Elementary Clinic SCNM has offered a naturopathy clinic at the Arthur M. Hamilton Elementary in Phoenix. The elementary school primarily serves [poor](/wiki/Poor) families. Despite the most prevalent health issues including including serious problems (diabetes, asthma, ADD) that are treatable by evidence-based medicine, SCNM offers ineffective treatments (acupuncture, physical medicine, supplementation and homeopathy). [[19]](#cite_note-19) - Mission of Mercy Arizona Mission of Mercy Arizona is a [Christian](/wiki/Christian) non-profit organization that provides free health care to people who cannot afford it. [[20]](#cite_note-20) SCNM students partner with the Mission of Mercy while staying out of the way of actual medical providers and not providing naturopathic treatments while possibly offending poor people about their "lifestyles" ("You will learn to work efficiently alongside conventional medical providers, and you will use modalities such as medications and lifestyle changes."). [[21]](#cite_note-21) - The River Source The River Source is a for-profit naturopathic addiction treatment center based on the twelve-step methodology of [Alcoholics Anonymous](/wiki/Alcoholics_Anonymous). [[22]](#cite_note-22) River Source has stated that its programs are cheaper than others because "have a partnership with the Southwest College of Naturopathic Medicine, allowing us to offer the latest advances in naturopathic medicine at a reduced cost." [[23]](#cite_note-23) Despite this claim, SCNM has offered archaic, ineffective (acupuncture, cupping therapy) and potentially dangerous treatments ( [detox](/wiki/Detox), nutritional IV therapy) at River Source. [[24]](#cite_note-24) - Sojourner Center The Sojourner Center is a large center in Phoenix that offers support to victims of [domestic violence](/wiki/Domestic_violence). It is an entirely independent organization. Both the SCNM and the Phoenix Children's Hospital Medical Mobile Unit have offered free on-site healthcare to transitional housing participants of the Center. [[25]](#cite_note-25) It is unclear how cases where [evidence-based medical](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine) advice contradicts naturopathic advice are handled. The SCNM has stated that they offer the "full scope of naturopathic modalities", including "acupuncture, homeopathy, [supplementation](/wiki/Vitamin_and_mineral_supplements) and [botanicals](/wiki/Herbal_supplement)" to participants. [[26]](#cite_note-26) - Southwest Center for HIV/AIDS Clinic [HIV/AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS) The Southwest Center for HIV/AIDS Clinic existed from around 2014-2018. [[27]](#cite_note-27) It offered both nauropathic-but-ineffective (acupuncture, synthetic prophylaxis (PrEP, presumably Truvada). [[29]](#cite_note-29) - World Addiction and Health Institute The World Addiction and Health Institute (WAMI) existed from about 2014-2017 [[30]](#cite_note-30) under the direction of David Arneson, an ND, who got his degree at SCNM. [[1]](#cite_note-faculty-1) The treatments ranged from possibly helpful (counseling) to useless (acupuncture, homeopathy to the potentially dangerous (nutritional IV therapy).
